abstract.p: Brayton Harris letter on Richard Woodward's March 11 travel article on visit to Paris

block.p: To the Editor: Richard B. Woodward's ''Paris; Making a Pilgrimage to Cathedrals of Commerce'' (Cultured Traveler, March 11) left out the most interesting bit of all. The panorama, circa 1800, was a device for exhibiting a huge painting, stretched across a stage between two posts. Viewers paid a small admission for the privilege of seeing the painting unfurled. The panorama was patented in France by an American artist and inventor living in Paris named Robert Fulton (known primarily for inventing the steamboat). The first painting exhibited on this particular panorama was ''The Burning of Moscow,'' painted by Mr. Fulton himself.
